title: Proof That Obama Has Not "Destroyed" The Economy

content: The stock market rose FOUR points and you're celebrating? ;-) Actually the stock market WANTS to rise. It could be argued that it rises only when Obama is NOT saying he'll spend money. When good (non-government) news comes out.. such as Ford independently cutting costs without a bailout.. the market rises. However, then Fannie Mae says "oops.. we need 30 billion more dollars!) and.... whoops there it goes again! It is almost a direct correlation between government spending announcements and stock market drops. The reasoning is simple... the investors (and business owners) don't want more spending (debt) and they don't like surprises (such as .. surprise.. another gov't program!) So, the market reacts badly to these. However, the basics are there for at least stock market equilibrium if not a rise. The fundamentals are still sound. Just look at the month-long period between Bush and Obama when no one was announcing huge expenditures? Stock market leveled off around 8-8.5k for weeks. Then the new stimulus bills came and <droop!> If they'd leave the damn thing alone it'd be alright. Yet every announcement is prefaced with DOOM AND GLOOM! This scares people and while is good for pushing unpopular programs on frightened people (universal health care anyone? More money for foodstamps?)... it's NOT good for promoting the economy. What we need now is confidence... since THAT is what our monetary system is based on. It's not based on money per se... it's based on FAITH in our system. Throwing money at the problem and deficit spending got us INTO this mess. More won't get us out of it... "Common sense isn't."

content: Just a little word of caution. Don't ever look at daily gains or losses when getting a feel for the environment. It is usually best to look at weekly trends (usually, monthly trends), as this gives a better overall picture. Sure, 300 points in a day is significant. But, if the trend is down for the week, then that 300 points means nothing. I've been investing for as long as I have been working. I have lost hundreds over the course of hours or less and have gained hundreds over the same period. But, that means nothing. I look at the total percentage over the course of a month. I usually shoot for 5%. It doesn't always happen, but it does more often than not. If I let a $10,000 loss in a day get me down, then I will not have my head about me. That is when I will cease to become an investor and start to become a speculator, or worse, a gambler. Tell me what the Dow, S&P, NASDAQ and Whilshire are at 1600 Friday. Then maybe we can have something. Now, stocks can be looked at daily. But, that is totally different than composites.

content: As I recall the stock market TANKED after 9-11 (caused in part by Clinton's ineptitude in pursuing terrorists.) The stock market only GOT to 14,000 under Bush. So... that would make him the best president in HISTORY by that measure? I could also point out that a commission set out to investigate real estate overvaluation and overspeculation was told by... dun dun dun Barney Frank among (most vocally among others) that the market wasn't HOT ENOUGH and that more risks should be taken to encourage more people to buy into it. Notice that the stock market did GOOD for weeks there (hovered around 8,000-8,500 consistently) when no government intervention was taking place. Then, once the Stimulus bill and TARP 2 happened... it tanked again. Stop playing with it and it'll return on its own.... "Common sense isn't."

content: Just a little word of caution. Don't ever look at daily gains or losses when getting a feel for the environment. It is usually best to look at weekly trends (usually, monthly trends), as this gives a better overall picture. Sure, 300 points in a day is significant. But, if the trend is down for the week, then that 300 points means nothing. I've been investing for as long as I have been working. I have lost hundreds over the course of hours or less and have gained hundreds over the same period. But, that means nothing. I look at the total percentage over the course of a month. I usually shoot for 5%. It doesn't always happen, but it does more often than not. If I let a $10,000 loss in a day get me down, then I will not have my head about me. That is when I will cease to become an investor and start to become a speculator, or worse, a gambler. Tell me what the Dow, S&P, NASDAQ and Whilshire are at 1600 Friday. Then maybe we can have something. Now, stocks can be looked at daily. But, that is totally different than composites.

content: As I recall the stock market TANKED after 9-11 (caused in part by Clinton's ineptitude in pursuing terrorists.) The stock market only GOT to 14,000 under Bush. So... that would make him the best president in HISTORY by that measure? I could also point out that a commission set out to investigate real estate overvaluation and overspeculation was told by... dun dun dun Barney Frank among (most vocally among others) that the market wasn't HOT ENOUGH and that more risks should be taken to encourage more people to buy into it. Notice that the stock market did GOOD for weeks there (hovered around 8,000-8,500 consistently) when no government intervention was taking place. Then, once the Stimulus bill and TARP 2 happened... it tanked again. Stop playing with it and it'll return on its own.... "Common sense isn't."

title: Proof That Obama Has Not "Destroyed" The Economy

content: The stock market rose FOUR points and you're celebrating? ;-) Actually the stock market WANTS to rise. It could be argued that it rises only when Obama is NOT saying he'll spend money. When good (non-government) news comes out.. such as Ford independently cutting costs without a bailout.. the market rises. However, then Fannie Mae says "oops.. we need 30 billion more dollars!) and.... whoops there it goes again! It is almost a direct correlation between government spending announcements and stock market drops. The reasoning is simple... the investors (and business owners) don't want more spending (debt) and they don't like surprises (such as .. surprise.. another gov't program!) So, the market reacts badly to these. However, the basics are there for at least stock market equilibrium if not a rise. The fundamentals are still sound. Just look at the month-long period between Bush and Obama when no one was announcing huge expenditures? Stock market leveled off around 8-8.5k for weeks. Then the new stimulus bills came and <droop!> If they'd leave the damn thing alone it'd be alright. Yet every announcement is prefaced with DOOM AND GLOOM! This scares people and while is good for pushing unpopular programs on frightened people (universal health care anyone? More money for foodstamps?)... it's NOT good for promoting the economy. What we need now is confidence... since THAT is what our monetary system is based on. It's not based on money per se... it's based on FAITH in our system. Throwing money at the problem and deficit spending got us INTO this mess. More won't get us out of it... "Common sense isn't."

title: Proof That Obama Has Not "Destroyed" The Economy

content: As I recall the stock market TANKED after 9-11 (caused in part by Clinton's ineptitude in pursuing terrorists.) The stock market only GOT to 14,000 under Bush. So... that would make him the best president in HISTORY by that measure? I could also point out that a commission set out to investigate real estate overvaluation and overspeculation was told by... dun dun dun Barney Frank among (most vocally among others) that the market wasn't HOT ENOUGH and that more risks should be taken to encourage more people to buy into it. Notice that the stock market did GOOD for weeks there (hovered around 8,000-8,500 consistently) when no government intervention was taking place. Then, once the Stimulus bill and TARP 2 happened... it tanked again. Stop playing with it and it'll return on its own.... "Common sense isn't."
